sen.j: 武道（ぶどう）とは、伝統的な日本武術（古武道）から発展したもので、人を殺傷・制圧する技術に、その技を磨く稽古を通じて人格の完成をめざす、といった芸道の面が加わったものである。
sen.e: Budo has developed from a traditional Japanese martial art ("kobudo", old budo), added the aspect of "geido" (the way of artistic self-discipline) which aims the perfection of character through practices to hone the skills to the techniques to kill or conquer the others.

Budo has developed from a traditional Japanese martial art ("kobudo," old budo), to which has been added the aspect of "geido" (the way of artistic self-discipline), which aims for the perfection of character through practices to hone the skills, to the techniques to kill or conquer others.

Budo has developed from a traditional Japanese martial art ("kobudo," old budo), to which has been added the aspect of "geido" (the way of artistic self-discipline), which aims for the perfection of character through practices to hone the skills, to the techniques to kill or conquer others.

sen.j: 道の追求という点については、残心（残身、残芯）などの共通する心構え所作などから茶道や日本舞踊、芸道ともかかわりを持つ。
sen.e: In pursuit of the "do or michi" (the way), it has something to do with "sado" (the way of tea), "nihon buyo" (Japanese dance) or "geido" in that they share the common mental attitudes or movements like "zanshin" (a state of awareness – of relaxed alertness and spelled as 残心, 残身, 残芯).

In pursuit of the "do or michi (the way)," it has something to do with "sado (the way of tea)," "nihon buyo (Japanese dance)" or "geido" in that they share the common mental attitudes or movements, such as "zanshin" (a state of awareness; of relaxed alertness, which is spelled as 残心, 残身, 残芯).

In pursuit of the "do" or "michi" (the way), it has something to do with "sado" (the way of tea), "nihon buyo" (Japanese dance) or "geido" in that they share the common mental attitudes or movements, such as "zanshin" (a state of awareness; of relaxed alertness, which is spelled as 残心, 残身, 残芯).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションマークの後に括弧を表記しました。

sen.j: 武道の理念は流派、武道家により様々であり、正反対の考え方さえ存在している。
sen.e: The ideal of budo varies from one school to another or from one martial artist to another, and even the contradictory views exist.
The ideal of budo varies from one school to another or from one martial artist to another, and contradictory views exist.
The ideal of budo varies from one school to another or from one martial artist to another, and contradictory views exist.

sen.j: 「武道」という言葉は江戸時代には武士道のことを指したが、江戸時代後期頃から武術のことも指すようになった。
sen.e: The word "budo" referred to the Bushido (Japanese chivalry) in the Edo period, but around the later Edo period it also came to refer to bujutsu (martial arts).
The word "budo" referred to the Bushido (Japanese chivalry) in the Edo period, but late in the Edo period it also became a reference to bujutsu (martial arts).
The word "budo" referred to the Bushido (Japanese chivalry) in the Edo period, but late in the Edo period it also became a reference to bujutsu (martial arts).

sen.j: 明治時代に、武術は廃れ、武術興行などを行いなんとか命脈を保つ状態となった。
sen.e: In the Meiji period, bujutsu became old-fashioned and barely came through by giving a bujutsu performance.
In the Meiji period, bujutsu became old-fashioned and survived only through means of bujutsu performances.
In the Meiji period, bujutsu became old-fashioned and survived only through means of bujutsu performances.

sen.j: このような中、嘉納治五郎は柔術を独自に理論化・合理化した柔道を開き乱取り稽古を盛んに行い大いに栄えた。
sen.e: Under such a situation, Jigoro KANO theorized and rationalized jujutsu (a kind of Japanese martial art styles including unarmed and armed techniques) in his own way, developed judo from it, did lots of "randori" (free-style) practices and flourished.

Given the situation, Jigoro KANO theorized and rationalized jujutsu (a kind of Japanese martial art style including unarmed and armed techniques) in his own way, developed judo from it, did lots of "randori" (free-style) practice, and thus flourished.

Given the situation, Jigoro KANO theorized and rationalized jujutsu (a kind of Japanese martial art style including unarmed and armed techniques) in his own way, developed judo from it, did lots of "randori" (free-style) practice, and thus flourished.

sen.j: これを参考に日清戦争直後の明治末から大正にかけて、これまでの技術が主となる内容ではなく教育的効用や精神修養を重んじる風潮となり（剣道家の高野佐三郎の歌にも「剣道は神の教えの道なれば やまと心をみがくこの技」とある）日本の伝統的な戦闘技法である日本武術を大日本帝国臣民としての精神修養としての道とし、学校教育に採用した。
sen.e: With reference to this, the trend came to have the contents which emphasized not the traditional techniques but the educational effect or mental training from the end of the Meiji period to the Taisho period just after the Japanese-Sino War (in the song of the master of kendo, Sasaburo TAKANO, "as kendo is the way of God's instructions, cultivate the 'yamato-gokoro' (Japanese spirit) by way of the sword"), and Japanese bujutsu as the way of Japanese traditional fighting skills was adopted in school education for the way of mental training of the subject under the Empire of Japan.

With reference to this, the trend came to have content that emphasized not the traditional techniques but the educational effect, or mental training, from the end of the Meiji period to the Taisho period, just after the Japanese-Sino War (in the song of the kendo master Sasaburo TAKANO, "As kendo is the way of God's instructions, cultivate the 'yamato-gokoro' (Japanese spirit) by way of the sword"), and Japanese bujutsu as the way of Japanese traditional fighting skills was adopted in school education as a means to promote mental training in the subject under the Empire of Japan.

With reference to this, the trend came to have content that emphasized not the traditional techniques but the educational effect, or mental training, from the end of the Meiji period to the Taisho period, just after the Japanese-Sino War (in the song of the kendo master Sasaburo TAKANO, 'As kendo is the way of God's instructions, cultivate the "yamato-gokoro" (Japanese spirit) by way of the sword'), and Japanese bujutsu as the way of Japanese traditional fighting skills was adopted in school education as a means to promote mental training in the subject under the Empire of Japan.

sen.j: その背景について、福島大学教授の中村民雄や筑波大学名誉教授の渡辺一郎らの研究によると、武術興行などを行い堕落した（とみなされた）武術と区別するために、教育的に有用な真剣な修行という意味で「武道」という名称を用いたのであるという。
sen.e: On this point, according to the study by Tamio NAKAMURA, a professor in the Fukuoka University and Ichiro WATANABE, a professor emeritus in the Tsukuba University, the name "budo" was applied in the sense of the educationally useful and earnest training, to differentiate from bujutsu which was degenerated (or was regarded as such) because of the bujutsu performance and so on.

On this point, according to the study by Tamio NAKAMURA, a professor of Fukuoka University, and Ichiro WATANABE, a professor emeritus of Tsukuba University, the name "budo" was applied in the sense of educationally useful and earnest training in order to differentiate from bujutsu, which had degenerated (or was regarded as such) because of bujutsu performance and so on.

On this point, according to the study by Tamio NAKAMURA, a professor of Fukushima University, and Ichiro WATANABE, a professor emeritus of Tsukuba University, the name 'budo' was applied in the sense of educationally useful and earnest training in order to differentiate from bujutsu, which had degenerated (or was regarded as such) because of bujutsu performance and so on.
sen.cmt: 福島大学 に修正しました。

sen.j: この時に武道と呼ばれた内容は、現代武道、伝統武術の区別はなかったが、伝統武術のみを指す場合は「古武道」・「古流」などと呼ばれる事が多い。
sen.e: On this occasion, the martial art called "budo" did not distinguish the modern budo from the traditional one, but in the case of referring only to the traditional one, it is often called "ko budo" (old budo) or "koryu" (old style) and so on.

In this case, the martial art called "budo" didn't distinguish the modern budo from the traditional one, but as a reference only to the traditional one it is often called "ko budo" (old budo) or "koryu" (old style), etc.

In this case, the martial art called "budo" didn't distinguish the modern budo from the traditional one, but as a reference only to the traditional one it is often called 'kobudo' (old budo) or 'koryu' (old style), etc.

sen.j: 近年は「古武術」と呼ぶ場合もある。
sen.e: Recently it is sometimes called "ko bujutsu" (old bujutsu).
Lately, it is sometimes called "ko bujutsu (old bujutsu)."
Lately, it is sometimes called 'ko bujutsu' (old bujutsu).

tit.cmt: 小タイトルのため、一部小文字にしました。

sen.j: 学校教育において明治期には武術は教育に教育困難でかつ有害であるとされていたが、講道館や大日本武徳会による柔道（柔術）、剣術の統一の基本技制定や集団教育法など教授法改良により明治44年（1898年）に旧制中学校の課外授業に撃剣（剣術）と柔術が導入され、名称は武道、剣道、柔道とされ、必修の正課になった。
sen.e: Bujutsu was considered to be difficult to teach and harmful in school education in the Meiji period, but the "gekiken" (kenjutsu, swordplay) and jujutsu were introduced as an extra lesson in the old-education-system junior-high schools in 1898, through the improvement of pedagogical methods such as the method of mass education or the unification of the basic skills of judo (jujutsu) and kenjutsu, and the lessons were named "budo," "kendo" and "judo" as compulsory and formal subjects.

During the Meiji period, Bujutsu was considered to teach and harmful in school education, but in 1898 "gekiken" (kenjutsu, swordplay) and jujutsu were introduced as an extra lesson in the junior high schools of the old education system through the improvement of pedagogical methods such as the method of mass education or the unification of the basic skills of judo (jujutsu) and kenjutsu, and the lessons were called "budo," "kendo" and "judo" as compulsory, formal subjects.

During the Meiji period, Bujutsu was considered to be difficult and harmful in school education, but in 1898 "gekiken" (kenjutsu, swordplay) and jujutsu were introduced as an extra lesson in the junior high schools of the old education system through the improvement of pedagogical methods such as the method of mass education or the unification of the basic skills of judo (jujutsu) and kenjutsu by the Kodokan Judo Institute and Dainippon Butoku-kai (Great Japan Federation of Martial Arts), and the lessons were called "budo," "kendo" and "judo" as compulsory, formal subjects.
sen.cmt: 講道館、大日本武徳会 を追加しました。

sen.j: 連合国軍最高司令官総司令部により学校での教授は禁止されたが、昭和25年（1950年）に文部科学省の新制中学校の選択教材に柔道、昭和27年（1952年）に剣道が選ばれた。
sen.e: To teach them in school was forbidden by the General Headquarters (GHQ), but judo was applied in 1950 and kendo in 1952 as the optional training aids in new-education-system junior-high schools by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology.

To teach them in school was forbidden by the General Headquarters (GHQ), but judo was applied in 1950 and kendo in 1952 as optional training aids in the junior high schools of the new education system by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology.

To teach them in school was forbidden by the General Headquarters (GHQ), but judo was adopted in 1950 and kendo in 1952 as optional training aids in the junior high schools of the new education system by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology.

sen.j: 昭和28年（1958年）の中学学習指導要領で、相撲、剣道、柔道剣道、柔道などの武道が格技という名称で正課授業が行われた。
sen.e: Under the Education Ministry guidelines for junior-high schools in 1958, budo such as sumo, kendo, judo-kendo, judo and so on, which were named "kakugi" (combative sports), were taught as formal lessons.

Under the Education Ministry guidelines for junior high schools in 1958, budo such as sumo, kendo, judo-kendo, judo and so on, which were called "kakugi (combat sports)," were taught as formal lessons.

Under the Education Ministry guidelines for junior high schools in 1958, budo such as sumo, kendo, judo-kendo, judo and so on, which were called "kakugi" (combat sports), were taught as formal lessons.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションマークの後に括弧を表記しました。

sen.j: 格技の練習場は「格技場」であるが、地方自治体の体育館などでは「挌技場」という表記も見られる。
sen.e: The practice fields of kakugi are written as "格技場," but in the gymnasium of local governments they are also spelled as "挌技場."
The practice fields of kakugi are written as "格技場," but in the gymnasiums of local governments they are also spelled as "挌技場."
The practice fields of kakugi are written as '格技場,' but in the gymnasiums of local governments they are also spelled as '挌技場.'

sen.j: 平成元年（1989年）の新学習指導要領で格技から武道に名称がもどされた。
sen.e: The name "kakugi" was changed back to "budo" under the new Education Ministry guidelines in 1989.
The name "kakugi" was changed back to "budo" under the new Education Ministry guidelines in 1989.
The name "kakugi" was changed back to "budo" under the new guidelines by the Ministry of Education in 1989.
sen.cmt: 新学習指導要領→new guidelines by the Ministry of Education としました。

sen.j: スポーツとの関係をどうとらえるかは、以下のように、流派、武道家により様々である。
sen.e: How to think of the relation between budo and sports varies from one school to another or from one martial artist to another as follows.
The manner in which one perceives the relationship between budo and sports varies from one school to another or from one martial artist to another, as follows:
The manner in which one perceives the relationship between budo and sports varies from one school to another or from one martial artist to another, as follows:

sen.j: 「スポーツ」を「格闘技」に置き換えても同じようなとらえ方がそれぞれ存在する。
sen.e: Even if the "sport" is replaced with "kakutogi" (combative sports), the view which regards both of them as the same exists.
sen.cmt: 「同じようなとらえ方」が「スポーツと格闘技を同じととらえる」の意味だとすれば、「それぞれ存在する」の「それぞれ」は余分であると判断して訳しませんでした。
sen.e: Even if the "sport" is replaced with "kakutogi (combat sports)," there is a view that regards them as the same.
Even if the 'sport' is replaced with 'kakutogi' (combat sports), there is a view that regards them as the same.

sen.j: スポーツと武道は対立概念でありスポーツ性が増せば武道性は減る。
sen.e: Conceptually sports are contrary to budo and thus, the more sports-ness, the less budo-ness.
Conceptually, sports are contrary to budo, and thus the more of a sports aspect there is, the less of a budo aspect there will be.
Conceptually, sports are contrary to budo, and thus the more of a sports aspect there is, the less of a budo aspect there will be.

sen.j: スポーツと武道は対立概念ではなく、武道でありスポーツでもある事は可能。
sen.e: Conceptually sports are not contrary to the budo and thus, it is possible to be both sports and the budo at the same time.
Conceptually, sports aren't contrary to the budo, and thus it's possible to be both a sport and budo at the same time.
Conceptually, sports aren't contrary to the budo, and thus it's possible to be both a sport and budo at the same time.

sen.j: 武道の一部にスポーツの部分があるだけで、いくらスポーツの部分が多くなっても全体としてはあくまでも武道に過ぎない。
sen.e: The sport is just a part of the budo, whatever the sport-part increases; it is absolutely a part of the budo as a whole.
The sport is just a part of the budo, however much the sport part increases; it is absolutely a part of the budo as a whole.
The sport is just a part of the budo, however much the sport part increases; it is absolutely a part of the budo as a whole.

sen.j: ジョギング、チェスやヨガでさえ、スポーツなのだから、武道も当然、スポーツである。
sen.e: Even jogging, chess and yoga are in the sport, so the budo naturally belongs to the sport.
Even jogging, chess and yoga are in the sport, so the budo naturally belongs to the sport.
Even jogging, chess and yoga are in the sport, so the budo naturally belongs to the sport.

sen.j: したがってどんな形をとろうが武道はスポーツである。
sen.e: Thus, any budo belongs to the sport.
Thus, any budo belongs to the sport.
Thus, any budo belongs to the sport.

sen.j: スポーツの定義は曖昧であり、武道の定義はさらにも増して曖昧である。
sen.e: The definition of the sport is ambiguous and that of the budo is much more.
The definition of the sport is ambiguous, but that of the budo is even more so.
The definition of the sport is ambiguous, but that of the budo is even more so.

sen.j: だからこのようなことを考えるのは意味がない。
sen.e: Thus, it is meaningless to think of this.
sen.cmt: 上記和文35-46は逐次英訳しました。
sen.e: Thus, it is meaningless to think of this.
Thus, it is meaningless to think of this.

tit.e: The introduction of the game and competition
The introduction of the game and competition
The introduction of the game and competition

sen.j: 試合・競技を導入している武道もあるが、本来は、武道の一面に過ぎなかった。
sen.e: Though the game and competition are introduced into some of the budo, they were originally just parts of the budo.
Though the game and competition are introduced into some of the budo, they were originally just parts of the budo.
Although the game and competition are introduced into some of the budo, they were originally just parts of the budo.

sen.j: 節「嘉納治五郎が挙げた武道の特徴」で、嘉納治五郎がはじめて武道とした柔道で挙げられるように試合や形競技・演武競技をおこなってこそ武道という考え方もある。
sen.e: In the section 'the characters of budo according to Jigoro KANO,' some people think the essence of budo lies in the game, the "kata" (form) competition or demonstration competition as in judo which Jigoro KANO firstly put as a budo
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外の対処
sen.e: According to the section on 'the characters of budo according to Jigoro KANO,' some people think the essence of budo lies in the game, the "kata (form)" competition or demonstration competition, as in judo, which Jigoro KANO first put as a budo.

According to the section on 'the characters of budo according to Jigoro KANO,' some people think the essence of budo lies in the game, the "kata" (form) competition or demonstration competition, as in judo, which Jigoro KANO first put as a budo.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションマークの後に括弧を表記しました。

sen.j: しかし、合気道は誰もが武道と認めるが、ほとんどの流派は試合・競技は行わないよう、「それがない武道は武道とは言えない」ということはない。
sen.e: However, though aikido (art of weaponless self-defense) is regarded as a budo by all, most of the schools of aikido do not hold the games or competitions and so it is wrong to say, 'the budo without holding them can not be a budo.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外の対処
sen.e: However, though aikido (the art of weaponless self-defense) is regarded as a budo by all, most of the schools of aikido do not hold games or competitions and so it is wrong to say that 'the budo without holding them cannot be a budo.'

However, although aikido (the art of weaponless self-defense) is regarded as a budo by all, most of the schools of aikido do not hold games or competitions and so it is wrong to say that 'the budo without holding them cannot be a budo.'

sen.j: 武道の理想を達成するためには試合・競技を否定する者さえ存在する。
sen.e: Some people deny the game or competition to achieve the ideal of the budo.
Some people deny the game or competition in order to achieve the ideal of the budo.
Some people deny the game or competition in order to achieve the ideal of the budo.

sen.j: 試合・競技のある武道であっても、修行者によって目的は異なり、試合・競技を目標とする者がいる一方で、稽古を中心とし試合・競技にこだわらない者も存在する。
sen.e: Even in the budo which holds the game or competition, the aim varies from one disciplinant to another, and some aim to win them, others concentrate on their own training without sticking to them.
Even in the budo that holds the game or competition, the aim varies from one disciplinant to another; some aim to win, but others concentrate on their own training without sticking to them.
Even in the budo that holds the game or competition, the aim varies from one disciplinant to another; some aim to win, but others concentrate on their own training without sticking to them.

sen.j: 試合・競技に強いからといって、武道が持つ技術体系を高レベルで習得しているとは限らないことにも表れる。
sen.e: We know that those who are competitive in the game or competition do not always acquire the system of techniques of budo at high levels.
We know that those who are competitive in the game or competition don't always acquire the system of high-level budo techniques.
We know that those who are competitive in the game or competition don't always acquire the system of high-level budo techniques.

sen.j: 但し、武道というものは勝負に勝つことや高いレベルに達することが必ずしも至上命題ではないということを覚えておく必要があるだろう。
sen.e: In this regard, we need to remember that to win the game or to reach a higher level is not an absolute must.
In this regard, we need to remember that to win the game or reach a higher level isn't an absolute must.
In this regard, we need to remember that to win the game or reach a higher level isn't an absolute must.

sen.j: 稽古の成果を確認する意味で試合・競技を見据えて稽古する方が熱が入り易い。
sen.e: It is more enthusiastic to aim to win the game or competition in order to see the result of training.
There is more enthusiasm in aiming to win the game or competition in order to see the results of training.
There is more enthusiasm in aiming to win the game or competition in order to see the results of training.

sen.j: 試合・競技を中心に考えて取り組む傾向が強くなり、試合・競技以外の技術がおろそかになったり、技術が本来のものから変質し易い。
sen.e: Those who tend to concentrate only on the game or competition tend to neglect the skills except those of the game or competition, and their skills are likely to change from the essence.

Those who tend to concentrate only on the game or competition tend to neglect the skills other than those of the game or competition, and their skills are likely to change from those that are essential.

Those who tend to concentrate only on the game or competition tend to neglect the skills other than those of the game or competition, and their skills are likely to change from those that are essential.

sen.j: 現代では武道として大事なのは人格の形成、精神の鍛錬であり技術的なことなどはさして重要でなく、武術的な部分は精神的修行の必要な荒くれ者どもを集めるための方便に過ぎないとの考え方もある。
sen.e: In modern times, the important things in budo are the character formation and mental training, the skills are not so important and some people think that the bujutsu-part of budo is just an expedient to gather the rowdy fellows who need the mental training.

In modern times, the important things in budo are the formation of character and mental training; the skills aren't so important, and some people think the bujutsu-part of budo is just an expedient way to gather rowdy fellows who need mental training.

In modern times, the important things in budo are the formation of character and mental training; the skills aren't so important, and some people think the bujutsu-part of budo is just an expedient way to gather rowdy fellows who need mental training.

tit.e: The introduction of the game or competition
Introduction to the game or competition
Introduction to the game or competition

sen.j: 乱取りの機会が増える。
sen.e: There is an increase of the opportunity of "randori."
There is an increase in the opportunity of "randori."
There is an increase in the opportunity of "randori."

sen.j: 技の形骸化の防止。
sen.e: We can prevent the skills from losing substance.
We can prevent the skills from losing substance.
We can prevent the skills from losing substance.

sen.j: 技の改良や誤った伝承の修正が行われ易い。
sen.e: We can easily improve the skills and correct the wrong handing down of them.
We can easily improve the skills and correct the inappropriate ways they've been handed down.
We can easily improve the skills and correct the inappropriate ways they've been handed down.

sen.j: 試合用に過ぎないが正しい体裁きの感覚が早く身につく。
sen.e: The skills just for the game make us acquire the right sense of body movement.
The skills just for the game lead us to acquire the right sense of body movement.
The skills just for the game lead us to acquire the right sense of body movement.

sen.j: 体力が向上し易い。
sen.e: We can easily gain physical strength.
We can easily gain physical strength.
We can easily gain physical strength.

sen.j: その試合規則で有用な技術が重視され、それ以外の技術はおろそかになり易い。
sen.e: The useful skills in the rules of game are emphasized, but the other skills are likely to be neglected.
Useful skills in the rules of the game are emphasized, but the other skills are likely to be neglected.
Useful skills in the rules of the game are emphasized, but the other skills are likely to be neglected.

sen.j: また、どんな試合規則にしても（禁止技無しでさえ）一対一で合図と共に戦いが始まることが前提となり、不意打ちや隠し武器などを想定した技術までカバーすることは難しい。
sen.e: Also, on the premise that we start a one-to-one fighting by signal whatever the rules of game are (even without banned skills or techniques), it is difficult for us to acquire the skills which include surprise moves, hidden weapons and so on.

Also, on the premise that we start one-to-one fighting by signal, whatever the rules of game are (even without banned skills or techniques), it's difficult for us to acquire the skills that include surprise moves, hidden weapons and so on.

Also, on the premise that we start one-to-one fighting by signal, whatever the rules of game are (even without banned skills or techniques), it's difficult for us to acquire the skills that include surprise moves, hidden weapons and so on.

sen.j: 技よりも筋力やスピード重視に陥り易い。
sen.e: We are inclined to emphasize the muscle strength or speed rather than the skills.
We're inclined to emphasize muscle strength or speed rather than skills.
We're inclined to emphasize muscle strength or speed rather than skills.

tit.j: 形（型）競技・演武競技の導入
tit.e: The introduction of "kata" (form) competition and demonstration competition.
The introduction of "kata (form)" competition and demonstration competition
The introduction of "kata" (form) competition and demonstration competition
tit.cmt: クォーテーションマークの後に括弧を表記しました。

sen.j: 競技として試合・組手だけを行っていると、形（型）・演武はおろそかにされ易くなるので、形（型）競技・演武競技も同時に行えばそれを防ぐことができる。
sen.e: If we only hold the game and "kumite" (sparring), the "kata" and demonstration skills are likely to be neglected, and so by holding "kata" or demonstration competition at the same time we can avoid the neglect of them.

If we only hold the game and "kumite (sparring)," the "kata" and demonstration skills are likely to be neglected, and so by holding "kata" or demonstration competition at the same time we can prevent them from being neglected.

If we only hold the game and "kumite" (sparring), the "kata" and demonstration skills are likely to be neglected, and so by holding "kata" or demonstration competition at the same time we can prevent them from being neglected.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションマークの後に括弧を表記しました。

sen.j: 形（型）・演武を実用の観点からどのようなものをよいとするかは流派、武道家などにより様々であり客観的評価が困難である。
sen.e: From a practical point of view, which kind of the "kata" or demonstration is the best varies from one school to another, from one martial artist to another and so on, and is difficult to decide on objective assessments.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: From a practical standpoint, the question of which kind of "kata" or demonstration is best will vary from one school to another, from one martial artist to another and so on, and it's difficult to make such assessments objectively.

From a practical standpoint, the question of which kind of "kata" or demonstration is best will vary from one school to another, from one martial artist to another and so on, and it's difficult to make such assessments objectively.

sen.j: 結局のところ、見た目の美しさやスピードを重視した採点基準になってしまい、本来の姿から乖離してしまう（中国武術伝統拳と制定拳参照）。
sen.e: As a result, the criteria of point rating tend to emphasize the showy beauty or speed, and deviate from the essence of budo (See Chinese bujutsu "dento ken" (traditional Tai Chi) and "seitei ken" (new type of Tai Chi)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: As a result, the criteria for point ratings tend to emphasize the showy beauty or speed but deviate from the essence of budo (see the Chinese bujutsu "dento ken" (traditional Tai Chi) and "seitei ken" (the new type of Tai Chi)).

As a result, the criteria for point ratings tend to emphasize the showy beauty or speed but deviate from the essence of budo (see the Chinese bujutsu "dento ken" (traditional Tai Chi) and "seitei ken" (the new type of Tai Chi)).
sen.cmt: 括弧を一部修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、「美」は武道の三大要素「用・美・道」のひとつで大事なことだとの反論もある。
sen.e: However, some refute this on the ground that "bi" (Beauty) is essential because it is included in one of the three major elements of budo "yo (Usefulness), bi, do (Way).".
However, some refute this on the grounds that "bi (beauty)" is essential because it's included in one of the three major elements of budo, "yo (usefulness), bi, do (way)."
However, some refute this on the grounds that "bi" (beauty) is essential because it's included in one of the three major elements of budo, "yo" (usefulness), "bi" and "do" (way).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションマークの後に括弧を表記しました。

tit.j: 嘉納治五郎が挙げた武道の特徴
tit.e: The characters of budo according to Jigoro KANO
The characters of budo according to Jigoro KANO
The characters of budo according to Jigoro KANO

sen.j: 明治初期、柔道の開祖嘉納治五郎は柔道(武道)の特徴を次のように挙げた。
sen.e: In the early Meiji period, the originator of judo Jigoro KANO put the characters of judo (budo) as follows.
In the early Meiji period, the originator of judo, Jigoro KANO, expressed the characteristics of judo (budo) as follows:
In the early Meiji period, the originator of judo, Jigoro KANO, expressed the characteristics of judo (budo) as follows:

sen.j: 柔道(個別武道)が根本原理であること。
sen.e: Judo (individual budo) is the basic principle.
Judo (individual budo) is the basic principle.
Judo (individual budo) is the basic principle.

sen.j: 練習・試合することで、人格の完成をめざすこと。
sen.e: We aim to complete our character formation by practicing and playing a match.
We aim to complete the formation of our character by practicing and playing in matches.
We aim to complete the formation of our character by practicing and playing in matches.

sen.j: 全国組織があり、日本全国で練習・試合できること。
sen.e: There are the nationwide organizations and we can practice and play a match throughout Japan.
There are the nationwide organizations, and we can practice and play matches throughout Japan.
There are the nationwide organizations, and we can practice and play matches throughout Japan.

sen.j: 少数の基本技と多数の応用技があること。
sen.e: Judo has a few basic skills and a lot of applied ones.
Judo has a few basic skills and many applied ones.
Judo has a few basic skills and many applied ones.

sen.j: 試合競技があること。
sen.e: Judo holds the matches in tournaments.
Judo matches are held in tournaments.
Judo matches are held in tournaments.

sen.j: 昇段制度があること。
sen.e: Judo has the promotion system (dan-ranking).
Judo has a system of promotion (dan-ranking).

sen.j: 戦前に大日本武徳会が柔道・剣道・弓道に段級位制武道を採用（段位制は講道館が、級位制は警視庁 (内務省)が先行して採用）して以降、他の武道にも採用され現在に至っている。
sen.e: Since Dainippon Butoku-kai (Great Japan Martial Arts Association) applied the dan-kyu promotion system for judo, kendo and kyudo before the war (ahead of this, the dan promotion system had been applied by the Kodokan, the kyu promotion system by the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department (the Interior Ministry)), the other budos have also applied the promotion system.

Ever since Dainippon Butoku-kai (Great Japan Martial Arts Association) applied the dan-kyu promotion system for judo, kendo and kyudo before the war (previously, the dan promotion system had been applied by the Kodokan, the kyu promotion system of the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department (the Interior Ministry)), the other budos have also applied the promotion system.

Ever since Dainippon Butoku-kai applied the dan-kyu promotion system for judo, kendo and kyudo before the war (previously, the dan promotion system had been adopted by the Kodokan, the kyu promotion system by the Tokyo Metropolitan Police Department (the Interior Ministry)), the other budos have also adopted the promotion system.
sen.cmt: 大日本武徳会 既出のため、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: ただしその区分けはそれぞれ歴史的経緯があり、武道によりまったく異なる。
sen.e: However, the distinctions have respectively their own historical backgrounds, and totally vary from one budo to another.
However, the distinctions have their own respective historical backgrounds, which vary significantly from one budo to another.
However, the distinctions have their own respective historical backgrounds, which vary significantly from one budo to another.

sen.j: また判定によらず功績等により与えられる名誉段位がある。
sen.e: Also, honorable dan is sometimes given to those who have a superb achievement and so on in spite of the judgment.
Also, honorary dan are sometimes given to those who have superb achievements and so on, despite the judgment.
Also, honorary dan are sometimes given to those who have superb achievements and so on, despite the judgment.

sen.j: 武道においては、錬士・教士・（準範士）・範士の称号が広く制定されている。
sen.e: The tiles such as renshi, kyoshi, (jun-hanshi) and hanshi are often given in budo.
Titles such as renshi, kyoshi, (jun-hanshi) and hanshi are often given in budo.
Titles such as renshi, kyoshi, (jun-hanshi) and hanshi are often given in budo.

sen.j: これらの称号の起源は明治期において、大日本武徳会が武道に精励した者に対して精錬証を授けたことが後に錬士の称号制定につながっているとされ、達士（後に教士）、範士の称号とともに剣道の称号として成立したことによる。
sen.e: The origin of these titles is thought to lie in the fact that the title seirensyo (renshi) was given to those who practiced very hard in budo, which, allegedly, later led to the entitlement of renshi, and it came into existence as the title of kendo as well as the titles such as tatsushi (later, kyoshi) and hanshi during the Meiji period.

The origin of these titles is thought to lie in the fact that the title of seirensyo (renshi) was given to those who practiced very hard in budo, which supposedly led to the entitlement of renshi, and it came into existence as the title of kendo as well as the titles such as tatsushi (later, kyoshi) and hanshi during the Meiji period.

The origin of these titles is thought to lie in the fact that the title of seirensho was given to those who practiced very hard in budo, which supposedly led to the entitlement of renshi, and it came into existence as the title of kendo as well as the titles such as tatsushi (later, kyoshi) and hanshi during the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: これらの称号は後に居合道、杖道、弓道、空手などで広く見られる。
sen.e: Later, these titles were often given in iaido, jodo, kyudo and karate and so on.
Later, these titles were often given in iaido, jodo, kyudo, karate and so on.
Later, these titles were often given in iaido, jodo, kyudo, karate and so on.

tit.e: The theory of budo by Tsugumasa NANGO
The theory of budo by Tsugumasa NANGO
The theory of budo by Tsugumasa NANGO:
tit.cmt: コロンを追加しました。

sen.j: - 唯物論的弁証法により武道を科学として解明し、武道本質論、武技上達論、勝負論など確立したとしているが、理論に基づく成果が全く提示されていないという指摘がされている。
sen.e: He scientifically elucidated the budo by materialistic dialectic and established the essentialist theory of budo, the theory of proficiency of martial arts, the theory of duel and so on, but he is criticized as not having suggested any outcome based on the theories.

He scientifically elucidated the budo by means of materialistic dialectic and established the essentialist theory of budo, the theory of proficiency in martial arts, the theory of the duel and so on, but he is criticized as not having suggested any outcome based on those theories.

He scientifically elucidated the budo by means of materialistic dialectic and established the essentialist theory of budo, the theory of proficiency in martial arts, the theory of the duel and so on, but he is criticized as not having suggested any outcome based on those theories.

tit.e: Jinjas (shrines) that are deeply related to budo
Jinjas (shrines) that are deeply related to budo
Jinjas (shrines) that are deeply related to budo

sen.j: 鹿島神宮
sen.e: Kashima jingu (Kashima Shrine)
Kashima jingu (Kashima Shrine)
Kashima-jingu Shrine

sen.j: - 日本武術・武道の神とされ、「鹿島大明神」・「香取大明神」として道場に祀られることが多い。
sen.e: As these shrines are regarded as the gods of Japanese bujutsu and budo, the name "Kashima Daimyojin (鹿島大明神)" and "Katori Daimyojin (香取大明神)" are often enshrined in the dojo (training hall).
These shrines are regarded as the gods of Japanese bujutsu and budo, the name "Kashima Daimyojin (鹿島大明神)" and "Katori Daimyojin (香取大明神)" are often enshrined in the dojo (training hall).
These shrines are regarded as the gods of Japanese bujutsu and budo, and the name 'Kashima Daimyojin' (鹿島大明神) and 'Katori Daimyojin' (香取大明神) are often enshrined in the dojo (training hall).

sen.j: - 居合の始祖・林崎重信公を祀る。
sen.e: The originator of iai, Shigenobu HAYASHIZAKI, is enshrined there.
Shigenobu HAYASHIZAKI, the originator of iai, is enshrined there.
